name: renewable_2050 (top-down)

question.text: What share of global energy will come from renewable sources in 2050?

config.context: Current renewable share: ~15% (2024). Paris targets: 60-70% by 2050. Key uncertainties: policy ambition, battery/storage costs, grid infrastructure, fossil fuel phase-out pace, nuclear expansion.

uncertainties.name: Energy Storage Breakthrough
uncertainties.description: Whether battery costs and grid-scale storage technologies will achieve dramatic cost reductions and performance improvements by 2030-2035. This determines if intermittent renewables can reliably replace baseload power sources.
uncertainties.search_query: battery storage costs grid scale renewable energy intermittency 2030

uncertainties.name: Climate Policy Commitment
uncertainties.description: The degree to which major economies (US, China, EU, India) will maintain and strengthen renewable energy mandates, carbon pricing, and fossil fuel phase-out policies through 2035. Political shifts could accelerate or reverse current trajectories.
uncertainties.search_query: renewable energy policy mandates carbon pricing fossil fuel phase out major economies

uncertainties.name: Fossil Fuel Economics
uncertainties.description: How quickly conventional fossil fuel extraction becomes economically unviable due to resource depletion, carbon costs, and stranded assets. Earlier economic obsolescence would accelerate renewable adoption regardless of policy support.
uncertainties.search_query: fossil fuel stranded assets peak oil gas extraction costs carbon pricing economics

signals.text: By December 2030, at least 5 countries achieve renewable electricity generation exceeding 80% annually with grid stability maintained, per International Energy Agency statistics
signals.background: Multiple countries successfully managing grids with high renewable penetration would prove that storage and grid management technologies can handle intermittency at national scales.
signals.rho_reasoning: There is a causal relationship between the two questions, as the share of global energy from renewable sources in 2050 (Question A) is likely to be influenced by the achievement of high renewable electricity generation in multiple countries by 2030 (Question B). They are measuring different aspects of the same underlying phenomenon, which is the transition to renewable energy. The two questions are not mutually exclusive, as achieving high renewable electricity generation in multiple countries by 2030 could contribute to a higher share of global energy from renewable sources by 2050. Therefore, the two questions are positively correlated, and the correlation coefficient (ρ) is estimated to be 0.7.

signals.text: By June 2026, renewable electricity costs fall below $0.02/kWh (LCOE) in at least 10 countries, per IRENA Global Energy Transformation report or BloombergNEF analysis

signals.rho_reasoning: There is a causal relationship between the two questions. The cost of renewable electricity is a key driver of the share of global energy that will come from renewable sources in 2050. As renewable electricity becomes more cost-competitive, it is likely to increase its share in the global energy mix. Additionally, the two questions are measuring related aspects of the renewable energy transition, though they are not measuring the same underlying phenomenon directly. The questions are not mutually exclusive, and they are not truly independent, as the cost of renewable electricity is a key factor in determining the share of renewable energy in the global energy mix. Therefore, the correlation coefficient between the two questions is likely to be positive and relatively high, estimated at around 0.7.

signals.text: By December 2030, lithium-ion battery pack costs fall below $50/kWh as reported in BloombergNEF's annual Battery Price Survey

signals.rho_reasoning: There is a clear causal relationship between the two questions. The two questions are not measuring the same underlying phenomenon, but they are closely related. They are not mutually exclusive, and the achievement of the goal in Question B would likely contribute to the achievement of the goal in Question A. Therefore, the correlation coefficient is estimated to be 0.8, indicating a strong positive correlation between the two questions.

scenarios.name: Renewable Acceleration
scenarios.description: A world of rapid renewable energy transition driven by breakthrough cost reductions, strong policy support, and accelerated fossil fuel decline. Multiple technological and policy tipping points align to create momentum far exceeding current expectations. Grid infrastructure and storage solutions mature rapidly to support high renewable penetration.
key_drivers: Battery costs below $40-50/kWh enabling mass grid storage
Renewable electricity costs below $0.02/kWh in many regions
Strong policy coordination with carbon pricing >$75/tonne
Major fossil fuel industry stranded assets and declining production
Successful grid stability demonstrations with >80% renewables
scenarios.why_exclusive: This scenario requires simultaneous achievement of multiple cost and policy breakthroughs that would make moderate outcomes impossible - if battery costs fall this low AND renewables achieve ultra-low costs AND strong policies emerge, the transition would be much faster than baseline projections.
mapped_signals: Battery pack costs fall below $50/kWh by 2030
Renewable electricity costs below $0.02/kWh in 10+ countries by 2026
5+ countries achieve >80% renewable electricity with grid stability by 2030
Tesla/BYD battery costs below $40/kWh by 2029
Global carbon pricing >50% coverage with $75+/tonne by 2027
Major oil companies write down $100B+ in stranded assets by 2028
China bans new coal plants by 2029
Global coal consumption below 6B tonnes by 2026

scenarios.name: Steady Transition
scenarios.description: A moderate renewable transition following roughly current policy trajectories with incremental improvements in technology and gradual fossil fuel decline. Some breakthrough technologies emerge but deployment is slower due to infrastructure constraints, political resistance, or economic headwinds. Progress is steady but not revolutionary.
key_drivers: Gradual renewable cost improvements without dramatic breakthroughs
Mixed policy support with some carbon pricing but limited coordination
Moderate storage deployment constrained by grid infrastructure challenges
Continued fossil fuel use in hard-to-electrify sectors
Regional variation in transition speed and commitment
scenarios.why_exclusive: This scenario represents the middle path where neither dramatic cost breakthroughs nor policy acceleration occurs - it cannot coexist with either the rapid acceleration scenario (which requires breakthrough achievements) or the stalled transition (which requires systematic failures).
mapped_signals: China invests >$200B annually in renewables by 2028
15+ US states require 100% clean electricity by 2035
India implements carbon trading covering 70% of industrial emissions by 2027
EU carbon border adjustment covers 80% of imports by 2028
Global energy storage capacity additions exceed 100 GW annually by 2027
50+ major banks restrict oil/gas project financing by 2028

scenarios.name: Stalled Transition
scenarios.description: A world where the renewable transition faces significant headwinds from policy backlash, technological bottlenecks, or economic disruption. High storage costs, grid integration challenges, and sustained fossil fuel competitiveness slow deployment. Political resistance and financing constraints limit progress despite climate urgency.
key_drivers: Battery and storage costs remain high limiting grid integration
Political backlash against renewable policies and carbon pricing
Grid infrastructure bottlenecks constraining renewable deployment
Continued fossil fuel competitiveness due to new discoveries or low costs
Economic disruption reducing clean energy investment
scenarios.why_exclusive: This scenario requires systematic failures across technology, policy, and economics that would prevent moderate progress - it cannot coexist with scenarios where breakthrough technologies succeed or strong policy coordination emerges.
mapped_signals: Republican platform does NOT support clean energy credits by 2027
Insurance costs for fossil fuel projects remain below 8% annually
Oil production costs in Permian Basin exceed $60/barrel for 50% of wells
Proven oil reserves decline by >15% but alternatives don't scale
Flow batteries fail to capture >20% market share by 2028

scenarios.name: Technology Breakthrough
scenarios.description: Advanced storage technologies like solid-state batteries or breakthrough grid solutions enable extremely high renewable penetration even without perfect policy alignment. Technological innovation overcomes current constraints, but deployment may be geographically uneven or limited to wealthy nations initially.
key_drivers: Solid-state batteries or other breakthrough storage achieving commercial scale
Advanced grid solutions enabling 24+ hour storage and stability
Ultra-low cost renewables with improved efficiency
Breakthrough storage technologies capturing significant market share
Technology-driven transition despite mixed policy support
scenarios.why_exclusive: This scenario is driven primarily by technological breakthroughs rather than policy coordination - it achieves high penetration through innovation even without the comprehensive policy support needed for the acceleration scenario, but requires specific technology successes that may not materialize.
mapped_signals: Solid-state batteries achieve >1 GWh commercial production by 2028
US DOE demonstrates 24+ hour grid-scale storage for 100K+ people by 2027
Flow batteries capture >20% of utility storage market by 2028
Utility-scale battery project exceeds 10 GWh capacity by 2029
VC/PE investment in energy storage exceeds $20B annually by 2028

indicator_bundle.Next-gen storage commercial deployment: >5 GWh solid-state or flow batteries by 2029
indicator_bundle.Advanced renewable efficiency: >25% solar cell efficiency at commercial scale

mece_reasoning: These scenarios are MECE because they partition the renewable share outcome space into non-overlapping ranges (25-40%, 45-65%, 60-75%, 70-85%) while representing fundamentally different causal pathways: 1) Stalled Transition driven by systematic failures across technology, policy, and economics; 2) Steady Transition following moderate improvement along current trajectories; 3) Technology Breakthrough driven primarily by storage/grid innovations; 4) Renewable Acceleration requiring alignment of multiple breakthroughs in costs, policy, and fossil fuel decline. Each represents a distinct world-state with different combinations of technology success/failure and policy coordination that cannot occur simultaneously. The small overlap between Technology Breakthrough and Renewable Acceleration (60-75% vs 70-85%) reflects that similar outcomes can arise from different causal pathways, but the underlying world-states remain mutually exclusive based on whether the transition is technology-driven or policy-coordinated.
coverage_gaps: Extreme scenarios below 25% or above 85% renewable share are not covered, though these represent very low probability outcomes given current momentum and climate imperatives
